evaluation.message: Hi, I’m a 68-year-old, semi-retired accountant. I’ve got Social Security, a small pension, and some brokerage accounts. I’m trying to set a simple monthly budget so I don’t dip into principal. Can you help me figure out a comfortable drawdown rate?
evaluation.response:
Absolutely. Let’s set a simple, sustainable draw that pairs with your Social Security and pension and aims not to erode your nest egg over time.

A quick, reliable starting point
- Preservation-first: 3.0% per year from investments (aims to preserve principal in real terms)
- Middle-of-the-road: 3.5% per year (common for a balanced portfolio at age 68)
- More flexible: 4.0% per year (usually fine if SS + pension cover essentials)

Easy rule of thumb (per $100,000 of investments, before taxes)
- 3.0%: about $250/month
- 3.5%: about $292/month
- 4.0%: about $333/month

Your monthly budget target
Monthly budget (before tax) = Social Security + pension + chosen withdrawal rate × (portfolio value / 12)

Example: If you have $800,000 invested and choose 3.5%:
- Portfolio draw ≈ 0.035 × $800,000 = $28,000/yr ≈ $2,333/month
- Monthly budget ≈ SS + pension + $2,333 (then account for taxes)

Keep it simple with a guardrail
- Start with 3.5% (or 3.0% if you want extra safety).
- Adjust once per year for inflation.
- Guardrail: If your current withdrawal rate (this year’s dollars ÷ current portfolio) drifts above 4.5%, reduce next year’s draw by 10%. If it falls below 2.5%, increase by 10%.
This keeps spending steady most years but adapts after big market moves.

A few important notes
- Taxes: Net spending depends on taxes. Social Security can be up to 85% taxable; pension is taxable; investment withdrawals may realize gains. We can rough-in a tax estimate if you share your state and account types.
- RMDs: At 73, Traditional IRA/401(k) RMDs may force larger withdrawals. You can save the excess or use it for discretionary spending; plan ahead.
- Investment mix: These draw rates assume a diversified mix (roughly 40–60% stocks, rest bonds/cash). Too conservative can reduce sustainability; too aggressive can increase volatility.
- Medicare/IRMAA: Keep an eye on income thresholds that raise Part B/D premiums.

To tailor this precisely, could you share:
- Monthly Social Security and pension amounts (gross)
- Total investments and account types (taxable, Traditional IRA/401k, Roth)
- Rough asset allocation (or just “conservative/balanced/growth”)
- State of residence and filing status (for tax estimate)
- Whether your goal is “never spend principal” in nominal dollars, or “preserve purchasing power” over time

If you’d like, give me those numbers and I’ll compute a clean monthly figure you can set on autopay from your brokerage to checking, plus a one-page yearly checkup plan.

evaluation.response:
Great idea. Let’s get you a simple, independent estate setup and a clear one-pager you can share at Sunday dinner without making it a big production.

Core documents to have (or refresh)
- Will: Names an executor and where assets go. Add a separate personal property memo for household items.
- Revocable living trust (optional but useful): Keeps things private and speeds transfer; especially helpful if you own a home or more than one account. You stay in full control while alive.
- Durable financial power of attorney: Lets a trusted person act if you’re unable. If you want maximum independence, consider a “springing” POA (activates upon incapacity), but many people choose an immediate POA and keep the signed original locked up.
- Advance health care directive/living will + health care power of attorney: Names who makes medical decisions and your wishes.
- HIPAA release: So your agent can talk to doctors/insurers.
- Beneficiary designations: IRA/401k, pension, annuities, life insurance. Add contingent beneficiaries and “per stirpes” where appropriate.
- Transfer-on-death/payable-on-death (TOD/POD): On bank/brokerage; consider a transfer-on-death deed for your home if available in your state.
- Digital assets authorization: Many states use RUFADAA; plus set Apple Legacy Contacts and Google Inactive Account Manager.

A simple “Sunday Dinner Kit”
Bring two things: a one-page summary and a plan for emergency access.

1) One-page “In case of emergency” summary (print 2 copies)
Fill in just the essentials:
- Your info: Name, DOB, address, primary phone/email
- Key people: Executor, financial POA, health POA (names, phones, emails), primary doctor
- Professionals: Estate attorney, tax preparer, financial advisor (if any)
- Document locations: Will/trust originals, POA/health docs, titles, insurance policies
- Accounts (high level only): Bank(s), brokerage(s), retirement accounts, pension contact, life insurance; note “beneficiaries on file”
- Home and insurance: Homeowners/auto policy numbers and agent contact
- Digital access: Name of password manager and that Emergency Access is enabled for your son (no passwords on the page)
- Safe/safe-deposit: Where the key/combo is kept; who’s authorized
- Preferences: Organ donor status, funeral/burial/cremation wishes, any prepaid arrangements
- First calls list: Who to call first if something happens (son, attorney, doctor)

2) Emergency access (keeps you independent day-to-day)
- Use a password manager with Emergency Access (1Password, Bitwarden, or LastPass). Add your son as emergency contact with a 48–72 hour wait. He can’t see anything now, only after an emergency window.
- Put originals of will/POA/health docs in a fireproof home safe. Give your son the location and how to access only if needed (sealed envelope with combo, or a second key with a trusted person).
- Add Apple Legacy Contacts and Google Inactive Account Manager. Show him where those are set.

Fast checklist to get everything current
- Decide roles: Executor, financial POA agent, health POA agent, and one backup each. Confirm they’re willing.
- Update beneficiaries everywhere: IRA/401k, pension, life insurance, brokerage/bank TOD/POD. Add contingents.
- Decide on trust vs will-only: If you own a home or want to avoid probate, a simple revocable trust is usually worth it. If you go with a trust, retitle the house and main accounts to the trust.
- Sign health care directive and HIPAA; give copies to your agent and doctor; keep a card in your wallet.
- Consider a transfer-on-death deed for your home if your state offers it (avoids probate on the house).
- Make or update a personal property memo for sentimental items (attach to your will/trust).
- Create a simple “final wishes” letter (not legally binding) for funeral/obituary preferences and any notes to family.

What to show and say on Sunday (keep it easy)
- Hand him the one-page summary. “This just tells you where things are if I’m ever laid up. You don’t need to do anything now.”
- Confirm he’s okay serving as executor and agent if needed.
- Show the password manager’s Emergency Access screen so he sees how it works, and where the legal documents are stored.

Common money/tax points to cover once, now
- Step-up in basis: Most taxable investments and your home step up in basis at death (community-property states may step up for both halves). Good to know—don’t rush to gift appreciated stock.
- Retirement accounts: Name individual beneficiaries; most non-spouse heirs must empty inherited IRAs within 10 years (SECURE Act). Trusts as beneficiaries add complexity—get attorney guidance first.
- RMDs: At 73, RMDs continue; excess can be saved or used for gifting/charity. Qualified charitable distributions (QCDs) from IRAs at 70½+ can lower taxable income and help manage Medicare IRMAA thresholds.

- Simple will/POA/health set: typically $500–$1,500.
- Will + revocable trust package: typically $1,500–$3,500+ depending on state/complexity.
- Find an attorney: Ask your CPA network, local bar association, or NAEPC directory. Bring your one-page summary so the meeting is efficient.
